notes: Alabama UC employer handbook lists family-member exclusions for individual owners and notes limits for corporations and partnerships.

rules.conditions_text: For an individual owner, wages paid to a spouse/parent/child under 21 are excluded from Alabama UI employment and not reported for UI.

authority.source_title: EMPLOYER HANDBOOK Unemployment Compensation (Alabama Department of Labor)
authority.supporting_quote: The individual owner of a business is not an employee, nor the parents, spouse, or the owners’ children under the age of 21.

rules.conditions_text: For an individual owner, wages paid to a spouse/parent/child under 21 are excluded from Alabama UI employment and not reported for UI.

authority.source_title: EMPLOYER HANDBOOK Unemployment Compensation (Alabama Department of Labor)
authority.supporting_quote: The individual owner of a business is not an employee, nor the parents, spouse, or the owners’ children under the age of 21.

rules.conditions_text: For an individual owner, wages paid to a spouse/parent/child under 21 are excluded from Alabama UI employment and not reported for UI.

authority.source_title: EMPLOYER HANDBOOK Unemployment Compensation (Alabama Department of Labor)
authority.supporting_quote: The individual owner of a business is not an employee, nor the parents, spouse, or the owners’ children under the age of 21.

rules.conditions_text: For a partnership, Alabama notes the family exclusion can depend on partners’ relationships to the worker.

authority.source_title: EMPLOYER HANDBOOK Unemployment Compensation (Alabama Department of Labor)
authority.supporting_quote: Family partnerships may have this exclusion applied based on the relationship of partners to workers.

rules.conditions_text: For a partnership, Alabama notes the family exclusion can depend on partners’ relationships to the worker.

authority.source_title: EMPLOYER HANDBOOK Unemployment Compensation (Alabama Department of Labor)
authority.supporting_quote: Family partnerships may have this exclusion applied based on the relationship of partners to workers.

rules.conditions_text: For a partnership, Alabama notes the family exclusion can depend on partners’ relationships to the worker.

authority.source_title: EMPLOYER HANDBOOK Unemployment Compensation (Alabama Department of Labor)
authority.supporting_quote: Family partnerships may have this exclusion applied based on the relationship of partners to workers.

rules.conditions_text: If the business is a corporation, the Alabama handbook says this family exclusion does not apply; wages are reportable.

authority.source_title: EMPLOYER HANDBOOK Unemployment Compensation (Alabama Department of Labor)
authority.supporting_quote: This exclusion does not apply if the entity is a corporation or non-family partnership.

rules.conditions_text: If the business is a corporation, the Alabama handbook says this family exclusion does not apply; wages are reportable.

authority.source_title: EMPLOYER HANDBOOK Unemployment Compensation (Alabama Department of Labor)
authority.supporting_quote: This exclusion does not apply if the entity is a corporation or non-family partnership.

rules.conditions_text: If the business is a corporation, the Alabama handbook says this family exclusion does not apply; wages are reportable.

authority.source_title: EMPLOYER HANDBOOK Unemployment Compensation (Alabama Department of Labor)
authority.supporting_quote: This exclusion does not apply if the entity is a corporation or non-family partnership.

notes: Alaska UI Tax newsletter (June 2024) explains how wages paid to a parent/spouse/child are reported differently for sole proprietors, partnerships, and LLCs.
For sole proprietors, exclusions apply unless the sole proprietor elects coverage.

rules.conditions_text: If you’re a sole proprietor and you pay your spouse for work, those wages are not reported for Alaska UI tax unless you elect coverage.

authority.source_title: Alaska Employer Newsletter — Unemployment Insurance Tax (June 2024)
authority.supporting_quote: of a sole proprietor should not be reported on the quarterly contribution report, unless the sole proprietor has elected coverage.

rules.conditions_text: If you’re a sole proprietor and you pay a parent for work, those wages are not reported for Alaska UI tax unless you elect coverage.

authority.source_title: Alaska Employer Newsletter — Unemployment Insurance Tax (June 2024)
authority.supporting_quote: of a sole proprietor should not be reported on the quarterly contribution report, unless the sole proprietor has elected coverage.

rules.conditions_text: If you’re a sole proprietor and you pay your child under 18 for work, those wages are not reported for Alaska UI tax unless you elect coverage.

authority.source_title: Alaska Employer Newsletter — Unemployment Insurance Tax (June 2024)
authority.supporting_quote: of a sole proprietor should not be reported on the quarterly contribution report, unless the sole proprietor has elected coverage.

rules.conditions_text: If you’re a sole proprietor and you pay your child (a full‑time student) under 21, those wages are not reported for Alaska UI tax unless you elect coverage.

authority.source_title: Alaska Employer Newsletter — Unemployment Insurance Tax (June 2024)
authority.supporting_quote: of a sole proprietor should not be reported on the quarterly contribution report, unless the sole proprietor has elected coverage.

rules.conditions_text: For an Alaska partnership, wages paid to a spouse/parent/child are reportable for UI tax.

authority.source_title: Alaska Employer Newsletter — Unemployment Insurance Tax (June 2024)
authority.supporting_quote: A parent, spouse or child of a partnership is reportable

rules.conditions_text: For an Alaska partnership, wages paid to a spouse/parent/child are reportable for UI tax.

authority.source_title: Alaska Employer Newsletter — Unemployment Insurance Tax (June 2024)
authority.supporting_quote: A parent, spouse or child of a partnership is reportable

rules.conditions_text: For an Alaska partnership, wages paid to a spouse/parent/child are reportable for UI tax.

authority.source_title: Alaska Employer Newsletter — Unemployment Insurance Tax (June 2024)
authority.supporting_quote: A parent, spouse or child of a partnership is reportable

rules.conditions_text: For an Alaska LLC, if your spouse/parent/child is not an LLC member and performs services, the wages are reportable for UI tax.

authority.source_title: Alaska Employer Newsletter — Unemployment Insurance Tax (June 2024)
authority.supporting_quote: who is not a member of a Limited Liability Company (LLC) and performs services for the business is reportable

rules.conditions_text: For an Alaska LLC, if your spouse/parent/child is not an LLC member and performs services, the wages are reportable for UI tax.

authority.source_title: Alaska Employer Newsletter — Unemployment Insurance Tax (June 2024)
authority.supporting_quote: who is not a member of a Limited Liability Company (LLC) and performs services for the business is reportable

rules.conditions_text: For an Alaska LLC, if your spouse/parent/child is not an LLC member and performs services, the wages are reportable for UI tax.

authority.source_title: Alaska Employer Newsletter — Unemployment Insurance Tax (June 2024)
authority.supporting_quote: who is not a member of a Limited Liability Company (LLC) and performs services for the business is reportable

notes: Arizona DES employer handbook page lists family-member exclusions and when the family exemption does not apply (corporations, certain partnerships, and certain LLC tax classifications).

rules.conditions_text: In Arizona, some family services are excluded (e.g., working for your spouse, or a child under 21 working for a parent), unless the family exemption is overridden by entity type.

authority.source_title: Unemployment Insurance Tax - Employees and Wages FAQ (Arizona DES)
authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: Individuals employed by their son, daughter or spouse, and individuals under the age of 21 years employed by their father or mother.

rules.conditions_text: In Arizona, some family services are excluded (e.g., working for your spouse, or a child under 21 working for a parent), unless the family exemption is overridden by entity type.

authority.source_title: Unemployment Insurance Tax - Employees and Wages FAQ (Arizona DES)
authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: Individuals employed by their son, daughter or spouse, and individuals under the age of 21 years employed by their father or mother.

rules.conditions_text: In Arizona, some family services are excluded (e.g., working for your spouse, or a child under 21 working for a parent), unless the family exemption is overridden by entity type.

authority.source_title: Unemployment Insurance Tax - Employees and Wages FAQ (Arizona DES)
authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: Individuals employed by their son, daughter or spouse, and individuals under the age of 21 years employed by their father or mother.

rules.conditions_text: Arizona says the family exemption does not apply when the employer is a corporation; wages are reportable.

authority.source_title: Unemployment Insurance Tax - Employees and Wages FAQ (Arizona DES)
authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: The employer is a corporation (this includes Subchapter S corporations)

rules.conditions_text: Arizona says the family exemption does not apply when the employer is a corporation; wages are reportable.

authority.source_title: Unemployment Insurance Tax - Employees and Wages FAQ (Arizona DES)
authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: The employer is a corporation (this includes Subchapter S corporations)

rules.conditions_text: Arizona says the family exemption does not apply when the employer is a corporation; wages are reportable.

authority.source_title: Unemployment Insurance Tax - Employees and Wages FAQ (Arizona DES)
authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: The employer is a corporation (this includes Subchapter S corporations)

rules.conditions_text: For partnerships (and multi‑member LLCs taxed as partnerships), the family exemption can depend on whether the relationship exists with all partners/members.

authority.source_title: Unemployment Insurance Tax - Employees and Wages FAQ (Arizona DES)
authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: unless an exempt family relationship exists between the employee and all of the partners or members

rules.conditions_text: For partnerships (and multi‑member LLCs taxed as partnerships), the family exemption can depend on whether the relationship exists with all partners/members.

authority.source_title: Unemployment Insurance Tax - Employees and Wages FAQ (Arizona DES)
authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: unless an exempt family relationship exists between the employee and all of the partners or members

rules.conditions_text: For partnerships (and multi‑member LLCs taxed as partnerships), the family exemption can depend on whether the relationship exists with all partners/members.

authority.source_title: Unemployment Insurance Tax - Employees and Wages FAQ (Arizona DES)
authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: unless an exempt family relationship exists between the employee and all of the partners or members

rules.conditions_text: For LLCs, Arizona ties the family exemption to how the LLC is treated for federal tax purposes (corporation vs partnership/sole prop).

authority.source_title: Unemployment Insurance Tax - Employees and Wages FAQ (Arizona DES)
authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: a partnership or limited liability company (LLC) treated as a corporation for federal tax purposes

rules.conditions_text: For LLCs, Arizona ties the family exemption to how the LLC is treated for federal tax purposes (corporation vs partnership/sole prop).

authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: a partnership or limited liability company (LLC) treated as a corporation for federal tax purposes

authority.pinpoint: What Is Exempt Employment? (Employees and Wages)
authority.supporting_quote: a partnership or limited liability company (LLC) treated as a corporation for federal tax purposes

notes: Arkansas DWS Employer Handbook lists family employment as 'Exempt Employment' (working for a son/daughter/spouse; child under 21 working for a parent).
todo: Confirm whether Arkansas has additional family exclusions (e.g., parent employed by child beyond the handbook bullet) in statute/rules and any entity-type limitations.

rules.conditions_text: Arkansas lists work performed for your spouse (individual employer) as exempt employment for UI reporting.

authority.source_title: Arkansas Division of Workforce Services — Employer Handbook (Aug 2022)
authority.supporting_quote: Service performed by an individual in the employ of his /her son, daughter, or spouse.

rules.conditions_text: Arkansas lists work performed for your child (individual employer) as exempt employment for UI reporting.

authority.source_title: Arkansas Division of Workforce Services — Employer Handbook (Aug 2022)
authority.supporting_quote: Service performed by an individual in the employ of his /her son, daughter, or spouse.

rules.conditions_text: Arkansas lists a child under 21 working for a parent (individual employer) as exempt employment for UI reporting.

authority.source_title: Arkansas Division of Workforce Services — Employer Handbook (Aug 2022)
authority.supporting_quote: Service performed by a child under twenty-one years of age in the employ of his /her father or mother.

notes: California EDD guidance summarizes CUIC §631 family employment exclusions (spouse, child under 18, and employment by an individual’s child/spouse).
EDD notes the §631 exclusion does not apply when the employing entity is a corporation.
todo: Confirm how CUIC §631 family exclusions apply to partnerships and LLCs (including tax classifications).

rules.conditions_text: If you pay your child under 18 to work for you as an individual employer, those wages are excluded from California UI coverage and not reported for UI.

authority.source_title: Family Employment (EDD, DE 231FAM)
authority.supporting_quote: Employment does not include service performed by a child under the age of 18 years in the employ of his father or mother.

rules.conditions_text: If you pay your spouse to work for you as an individual employer, those wages are excluded from California UI coverage and not reported for UI.

authority.source_title: Family Employment (EDD, DE 231FAM)
authority.supporting_quote: Employment does not include service performed by an individual in the employ of his son, daughter, or spouse.

rules.conditions_text: If you (as an individual) pay your parent for work and you are their child employer, that service is excluded from California UI coverage and not reported for UI.

authority.source_title: Family Employment (EDD, DE 231FAM)
authority.supporting_quote: Employment does not include service performed by an individual in the employ of his son, daughter, or spouse.

rules.conditions_text: Once your child is 18 or older, the EDD says the family exclusion no longer applies; wages are treated as covered employment for UI reporting.

authority.source_title: Family Employment (EDD, DE 231FAM)
authority.supporting_quote: As soon as a child reaches the age of 18, the exclusion no longer applies.

rules.conditions_text: EDD guidance says stepchildren are not included in the child-under-18 family exclusion; treat wages as reportable unless another exclusion applies.

authority.source_title: Family Employment (EDD, DE 231FAM)
authority.supporting_quote: This exemption includes adopted children under 18 years, but stepchildren are not included.

rules.conditions_text: If the employing entity is a corporation, EDD says the family exclusion in CUIC §631 does not apply; treat wages as reportable for UI.

authority.source_title: Family Employment (EDD, DE 231FAM)
authority.supporting_quote: Section 631 of the California Unemployment Insurance Code does not apply if the employing entity is a corporation.

rules.conditions_text: If the employing entity is a corporation, EDD says the family exclusion in CUIC §631 does not apply; treat wages as reportable for UI.

authority.source_title: Family Employment (EDD, DE 231FAM)
authority.supporting_quote: Section 631 of the California Unemployment Insurance Code does not apply if the employing entity is a corporation.

rules.conditions_text: If the employing entity is a corporation, EDD says the family exclusion in CUIC §631 does not apply; treat wages as reportable for UI.

authority.source_title: Family Employment (EDD, DE 231FAM)
authority.supporting_quote: Section 631 of the California Unemployment Insurance Code does not apply if the employing entity is a corporation.

rules.conditions_text: If the employing entity is a corporation, EDD says the family exclusion in CUIC §631 does not apply; treat wages as reportable for UI.

authority.source_title: Family Employment (EDD, DE 231FAM)
authority.supporting_quote: Section 631 of the California Unemployment Insurance Code does not apply if the employing entity is a corporation.

notes: Colorado statute excludes services performed by an individual employed by their spouse, and services performed by a child under 21 employed by their parent.
todo: Confirm whether Colorado has any additional family-member exclusions (e.g., parent employed by child) beyond C.R.S. §8-70-129.
Locate Colorado agency guidance clarifying how these exclusions apply to partnerships and LLCs.

rules.conditions_text: If you pay your spouse to work for you as an individual employer, Colorado excludes that service from UI employment.

authority.source_title: Colorado Employment Security Act (CESA)
authority.supporting_quote: Employment does not include services performed by an individual in the employ of his spouse.

rules.conditions_text: If you pay your child under 21 to work for you as an individual employer, Colorado excludes that service from UI employment.

authority.source_title: Colorado Employment Security Act (CESA)
authority.supporting_quote: service performed by a child under the age of twenty-one in the employ of his father or mother.

notes: Connecticut DOL claimant guide lists family employment examples under 'Employment Not Covered' (spouse for spouse; children under 21 working for a parent).
todo: Find the underlying Connecticut statute/regulation section for family employment exclusions and confirm any entity-type nuances (corporations, partnerships, LLCs).

rules.conditions_text: Connecticut DOL lists children under 21 employed by a parent as employment not covered for UI.

authority.source_title: Guide to Collecting Unemployment Benefits (Connecticut DOL)
authority.supporting_quote: Children under 21 employed by a parent and anyone employed by his or her spouse.

rules.conditions_text: Connecticut DOL lists someone employed by their spouse as employment not covered for UI.

authority.source_title: Guide to Collecting Unemployment Benefits (Connecticut DOL)
authority.supporting_quote: Children under 21 employed by a parent and anyone employed by his or her spouse.

notes: Delaware employer handbook describes family employment exclusions for individual employers and notes that work for a corporation run by family is still considered employment.
todo: Confirm Delaware statute/rule citation for the handbook's family employment section.
Clarify treatment for partnerships/LLCs beyond the handbook examples.

rules.conditions_text: Delaware excludes UI employment when an individual works directly for their spouse (individual employer).

authority.source_title: Delaware Unemployment Insurance Employer Handbook
authority.supporting_quote: By an individual in the employ of a son, daughter or spouse

rules.conditions_text: Delaware excludes UI employment when an individual works directly for their child (individual employer).

authority.source_title: Delaware Unemployment Insurance Employer Handbook
authority.supporting_quote: By an individual in the employ of a son, daughter or spouse

rules.conditions_text: Delaware excludes UI employment when a child under 18 works directly for a parent (individual employer).

authority.source_title: Delaware Unemployment Insurance Employer Handbook
authority.supporting_quote: service performed by a child under the age of 18 in the employ of his father or mother

rules.conditions_text: Delaware says the family exclusion does not apply when the worker is employed by a corporation run by family; treat wages as reportable.

authority.source_title: Delaware Unemployment Insurance Employer Handbook
authority.supporting_quote: if the individual is employed by a corporation run by a son, daughter or spouse, it is considered employment

rules.conditions_text: Delaware says the family exclusion does not apply when the worker is employed by a corporation run by family; treat wages as reportable.

authority.source_title: Delaware Unemployment Insurance Employer Handbook
authority.supporting_quote: if the individual is employed by a corporation run by a son, daughter or spouse, it is considered employment

rules.conditions_text: Delaware says the family exclusion does not apply when the worker is employed by a corporation run by family; treat wages as reportable.

authority.source_title: Delaware Unemployment Insurance Employer Handbook
authority.supporting_quote: if the individual is employed by a corporation run by a son, daughter or spouse, it is considered employment

rules.conditions_text: Delaware says the family exclusion does not apply when the worker is employed by a corporation run by family; treat wages as reportable.

authority.source_title: Delaware Unemployment Insurance Employer Handbook
authority.supporting_quote: if the individual is employed by a corporation run by a son, daughter or spouse, it is considered employment
